question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
A rectangular tile measures 3 inches by 4 inches. What is the fewest number of these tiles that are needed to completely cover a rectangular region that is 2 feet by 5 feet?
inference:
* Convert feet to inches:
$$\text{2 feet}=\text{24 inches and 5 feet}=\text{60 inches}$$
 
* Find the area of the rectangular region:
$$\text{Area}=\text{length}\times\text{width}$$
$$\text{Area}=24\times60=1440\text{ square inches}$$

* Find the area of one tile:
$$\text{Area}=3\times4=12\text{ square inches}$$

* Determine the number of tiles needed to cover the rectangular region:
$$\text{Number of tiles}=\frac{\text{Area of rectangular region}}{\text{Area of one tile}}$$
$$\text{Number of tiles}=\frac{1440}{12}=120$$

*Final Answer: $\boxed{120}$. I hope it is correct.*
ground_truth:
The area of the floor in square feet $5 \cdot 2 = 10$. Each tile has an area in square feet of $\left ( \dfrac{1}{4} \right ) \left ( \dfrac{1}{3} \right ) =
\dfrac{1}{12}$, so the minimum number of tiles is $\dfrac{10}{\left( \frac{1}{12} \right)} = \boxed{120}.$

question:

* Determine the number of tiles needed to cover the rectangular region:
$$\text{Number of tiles}=\frac{\text{Area of rectangular region}}{\text{Area of one tile}}$$
$$\text{Number of tiles}=\frac{1440}{12}=120$$

*Final Answer: $\boxed{120}$. I hope it is correct.*

ground_truth:
The area of the floor in square feet $5 \cdot 2 = 10$. Each tile has an area in square feet of $\left ( \dfrac{1}{4} \right ) \left ( \dfrac{1}{3} \right ) =
\dfrac{1}{12}$, so the minimum number of tiles is $\dfrac{10}{\left( \frac{1}{12} \right)} = \boxed{120}.$
